Title: Insula of the old world monkey. I: Architectonics in the insulo-orbito-temporal component of the paralimbic brain
Abstract:
"The insula of the rhesus monkey has a surface area of approximately 160 mm2 and can be divided into three architectonic sectors. The agranular sector is coextensive with prepiriform allocortex and is characterized by three agranular cellular strata, a zonal layer of myelinated fibers, and a high level of intracortical acetylcholinesterase (AChE). The dysgranular sector adjoins the agranular sector and shows first the emergence of a granular L4 and then a gradual differentiation of L2. Cortical myelin is low and mostly within deep layers; the AChE level is less than in the agranular sector. The third and granular sector covers the posterior aspect of the insula and contains granular L4 and L2, incipient sublamination of L3, increased cortical myelin with an emergent outer line of Baillarger, and a very low density of AChE. These observations indicate that AChE histochemistry can be used for the architectonic analysis of
cortex. The lateral orbital cortex and the temporal pole can also be subdivided into agranular, dysgranular, and granular regions. In the insula as well as in lateral orbital and temporopolar
areas, the agranular sector is directly contiguous with prepiriform cortex. When these three brain regions are considered jointly, they are seen to be organized in the form of increasingly
more differentiated agranular, dysgranular, granular, and hypergranular sectors arranged concentrically around prepiriform allocortex. The term paralimbic is suggested as a generic term
for all regions where such transitions occur from allocortex to granular isocortex. The insula, lateral orbital surface, and temporal pole are paralimbic areas with an olfactory allocortical
focus. The parahippocampal, retrosplenial, cingulate, and subcallosal regions constitute a second group of paralimbic areas with a hippocampal-induseal focus. In the most general sense, the functional specilizations of paralimbic areas are predominantly for behaviors which require an integration between extrapersonal stimuli and the internal milieu. The human insula has a plan of organization virtually identical to that in the rhesus monkey. In the human, the insulo-orbito-temporopolar component of the paralimbic brain may become involved in conditions which range from epilepsy to psychosomatic disease. "

@BrainMaps_Delineation.Region_Parcellation: Orbitofrontal cortex, insula, supratemporal plane, fronto-temporo-parietal operculum
@BrainMaps_Delineation.Citation: "Cytoarchitectonic maps of the insula and surrounding regions have been prepared for the old-world monkey by Roberts and Akert (1963) and by Jones and Burton (1976). Each map subdivides the insula into three major sectors: an anterior agranular component...a posterior six-layered granular moiety...and an intercalated dysgranular component...Our own architectonic observations...provide information to support and supplement each of these...maps. Furthermore, we have noted very close parallels between the organization of the insula and that of the lateral orbitofrontal and temporopolar regions." (p. 2)
@BrainMaps_Delineation.ImportantNewBrainSites: Ig, Idg, Ia-p, OFg, OFdg, OFa-p, TPdg, TPa-g

@BrainMaps_Methods.MethodicalDetails: cresyl violet staining for Nissl substance

@InterMapRelations.Comments: The list of abbreviations on page 4 states that Mesulam & Mufson (1982 ) have defined their areas 3, 1, 2 according to the parcellation scheme of Brodmann (1905).
The list of abbreviations on page 4 states that Mesulam & Mufson (1982) have defined their areas 3, 1, 2 according to the parcellation scheme of Brodmann (1905).
The list of abbreviations on page 4 states that Mesulam & Mufson (1982 ) have defined their areas 3, 1, 2 according to the parcellation scheme of Brodmann (1905).
In the list of abbreviations it is stated that area PF of MM82a corresponds to area PF of Bonin & Bailey ('47).
The list of abbreviations (p. 4) states unambiguously that both areas are identical.
See list of abbreviations, p.4.
See list of abbreviations, p.4.

There is no statement according to what parcellation scheme area AI is defined. We thus refer to a standard map for area AI (Merzenich and Brugge, 1973) and assume that MM82a-AI is identical to MB73-AI.
This assumption is chosen, because (i) both areas have the same abbreviation, and (ii) Jones and Burton ('76) are frequently cited for the description of SII.

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "On either side of this orbito-insular sulcus, the insula contains a dysgranular type of cortex (Idg)... It appears that Roberts and Akert (1963) as well as Jones and Burton (1976) would designate most of this anterior portion of the insula as agranular (Fig. 1D, E)." (pp. 3-4)

"On either side of this orbito-insular sulcus, the insula contains a dysgranular type of cortex (Idg)... It appears that Roberts and Akert (1963) as well as Jones and Burton (1976) would designate most of this anterior portion of the insula as agranular (Fig. 1D, E)." (pp. 3-4)

"On either side of this orbito-insular sulcus, the insula contains a dysgranular type of cortex (Idg)... It appears that Roberts and Akert (1963) as well as Jones and Burton (1976) would designate most of this anterior portion of the insula as agranular (Fig. 1D, E)." (pp. 3-4)
@InterMapRelations.Comments: A comparison of the maps (Figs. 1A, D, E), seems to support the implication from the citation above that agranular insular fields of RA63 and JB76 contain area Ia-p of MM82a.

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "On either side of this orbito-insular sulcus, the insula contains a dysgranular type of cortex (Idg)... It appears that Roberts and Akert (1963) as well as Jones and Burton (1976) would designate most of this anterior portion of the insula as agranular (Fig. 1D, E)." (pp. 3-4)
@InterMapRelations.Comments: A comparison of the maps (Figs. 1A, D, E), seems to support the implication from the citation above that agranular insular fields of RA63 and JB76 contain area Ia-p of MM82a.

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "Rostral to the emergence of insular cortex, the lateral orbital sulcus is surrounded by areas 11 and 13 medially and area 12 laterally (Walker, '40). At this level, both regions can be described as granular (OFg) since they contain sparsely granular but moderately well-demarcated layers 2 and 4... Lateral orbitofrontal cortex (areas 12 and 13 of Walker '40 ) thus changes from a granular to a dysgranular and then to an agranular-periallocortical arrangement along a rostrocaudal axis." (p. 3) "A similar pattern is present in the granular portion of orbitofrontal areas 12 and 13 (OFg)." (p. 13) "The third outer belt contains the granular portion of areas 12 and 13 ( OFg), ..." (p. 20)
@InterMapRelations.Comments:
Walker`s areas 12 and 13 show a mediolateral arrangement, however, Mesulam & Mufson, however, show a rostrocaudal arrangement for areas OFg, OFdg, OFa-p.
In summary (i) OFg contains area 11 and overlaps with areas12 and 13, and (ii) OFdg and OFa-p are overlapping with areas 12 and 13.

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "Posterior to OFO-Prco, the inner face of the parietal operculum is covered by areas 1 and 2 of somatosensory cortex (SI)." (p. 10)
"Posterior to OFO-Prco, the inner face of the parietal operculum is covered by areas 1 and 2 of somatosensory cortex (SI)." (p. 10)
"More posteriorly, the supratemporal plane contains the auditory cortex. Sanides (1972) has subdivided auditory cortex into proA (AII), Kam (medial AI), and Kalt (lateral AI)." (p. 10)
"More posteriorly, the supratemporal plane contains the auditory cortex. Sanides (1972) has subdivided auditory cortex into proA (AII), Kam (medial AI), and Kalt (lateral AI)." (p. 10)
"More posteriorly, the supratemporal plane contains the auditory cortex. Sanides (1972) has subdivided auditory cortex into proA (AII), Kam (medial AI), and Kalt (lateral AI)." (p. 10)
"According to Sanides (1968, 1970) and Jones and Burton (1976) OFO corresponds to a primary gustatory cortex (G)." (p. 10)
"The agranular-periallocortical part of the orbital surface has been designated "Allo" by Roberts and Akert ('63) and junctional cortex (J) by Jones and Burton ('76) (see Fig. 1D, E)." (p. 3)
"The agranular-periallocortical part of the orbital surface has been designated "Allo" by Roberts and Akert ('63) and junctional cortex (J) by Jones and Burton ('76) (see Fig. 1D, E)." (p. 3)

"At the most anterior levels of the insula, the inner surface of the frontal operculum is covered by a cortical region which has been designated by Roberts and Akert ('63) as OFO anteriorly and Prco caudally. " (p. 10)
@InterMapRelations.Comments: This statement is clarified by the list of abbreviations, which shows that OFO and Prco from MM82a are defined according to RA63.

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "Posterior to the insula, the supratemporal plane contains granular homotypical association areas which have been designated as postauditory cortex (PA) by Jones and Burton ('76 ) and reIt, paAc, and Tpt by Sanides ('72). " (p. 10)
@InterMapRelations.Comments: According to the list of abbreviations on p. 4, MM82a-PA is defined according to JB76.

"Posterior to the limen, this extension of TPdg on the supratemporal plane has been called parainsular cortex (PI in Fig. 1A,C,E )... Lateral to the supratemporal dysgranular cortex (PI), there is another longitudinal band of cortex with a granular cytoarchitecture. This supratemporal granular band (STPg) contains the areas Ts3 and paALT of Sanides (1972 ) and T1 and T2 of Jones and Burton (1976)... More posteriorly, the supratemporal plane contains the auditory cortex.Sanides (1972) has subdivided auditory cortex into proA (AII), Kam (medial AI), and Kalt (lateral AI)... Posterior to the insula, the supratemporal plane contains granular homotypical association areas which have been designated as postauditory cortex (PA) by Jones and Burton and reIt, paAc, and Tpt by Sanides (1972). " (p. 10)
@InterMapRelations.Comments: Shortly summarized, STP contains areas STPg, PI, PA, AI and AII.

@InterMapRelations_clean.Citation: "Rostral to the emergence of insular cortex, the lateral orbital sulcus is surrounded by areas 11 and 13 medially and area 12 laterally (Walker, '40). At this level, both regions can be described as granular (OFg) since they contain sparsely granular but moderately well-demarcated layers 2 and 4... Lateral orbitofrontal cortex (areas 12 and 13 of Walker '40 ) thus changes from a granular to a dysgranular and then to an agranular-periallocortical arrangement along a rostrocaudal axis." "Posterior to the limen, this extension of TPdg on the supratemporal plane has been called parainsular cortex (PI in Fig. 1A,C,E )... Lateral to the supratemporal dysgranular cortex (PI), there is another longitudinal band of cortex with a granular cytoarchitecture. This supratemporal granular band (STPg) contains the areas Ts3 and paALT of Sanides (1972 ) and T1 and T2 of Jones and Burton (1976)... More posteriorly, the supratemporal plane contains the auditory cortex.Sanides (1972) has subdivided auditory cortex into proA (AII), Kam (medial AI), and Kalt (lateral AI)... Posterior to the insula, the supratemporal plane contains granular homotypical association areas which have been designated as postauditory cortex (PA) by Jones and Burton and reIt, paAc, and Tpt by Sanides (1972). " (p. 10)

publication.title: Insula of the old world monkey. I: Architectonics in the insulo-orbito-temporal component of the paralimbic brain
publication.abstract:
"The insula of the rhesus monkey has a surface area of approximately 160 mm2 and can be divided into three architectonic sectors. The agranular sector is coextensive with prepiriform allocortex and is characterized by three agranular cellular strata, a zonal layer of myelinated fibers, and a high level of intracortical acetylcholinesterase (AChE). The dysgranular sector adjoins the agranular sector and shows first the emergence of a granular L4 and then a gradual differentiation of L2. Cortical myelin is low and mostly within deep layers; the AChE level is less than in the agranular sector. The third and granular sector covers the posterior aspect of the insula and contains granular L4 and L2, incipient sublamination of L3, increased cortical myelin with an emergent outer line of Baillarger, and a very low density of AChE. These observations indicate that AChE histochemistry can be used for the architectonic analysis of
cortex. The lateral orbital cortex and the temporal pole can also be subdivided into agranular, dysgranular, and granular regions. In the insula as well as in lateral orbital and temporopolar
areas, the agranular sector is directly contiguous with prepiriform cortex. When these three brain regions are considered jointly, they are seen to be organized in the form of increasingly
more differentiated agranular, dysgranular, granular, and hypergranular sectors arranged concentrically around prepiriform allocortex. The term paralimbic is suggested as a generic term
for all regions where such transitions occur from allocortex to granular isocortex. The insula, lateral orbital surface, and temporal pole are paralimbic areas with an olfactory allocortical
focus. The parahippocampal, retrosplenial, cingulate, and subcallosal regions constitute a second group of paralimbic areas with a hippocampal-induseal focus. In the most general sense, the functional specilizations of paralimbic areas are predominantly for behaviors which require an integration between extrapersonal stimuli and the internal milieu. The human insula has a plan of organization virtually identical to that in the rhesus monkey. In the human, the insulo-orbito-temporopolar component of the paralimbic brain may become involved in conditions which range from epilepsy to psychosomatic disease. "
